Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery closed vessel, probably a dinos; interior reserved; exterior, white slip: two friezes separated by single band; above, one hind leg and one foreleg of goat to right with part of rising roundel as filling ornament; below, pendant triangle as filling ornament with part of undetermined motif to right.
Producer name: Attributed to: Group of the Aphrodite Bowl
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as part of the Group of the Aphrodite Bowl rather than by the Painter of the bowl, because the sherd displays a greater amount of variety in the filling ornaments, albeit similar to those on the Aphrodite Bowl (Lemos 1991, 74-5). Whilst Lemos identifies the sherd as coming from an oinochoe, the sherd most likely comes from a dinos. Chian dinoi were not slipped on the interior and Williams notes the dinos sherds are often mistaken for oinochoai because of this (Williams 2006a, 128). Furthermore, Williams argues that British Museum 1888,0601.499.g, 1888,0601.499.b, 1888,0601.443 and 1924,1201.21 all belong to the same dinos (Williams 2006a, 132 note 29). 1924,1201.21 is an incorrect registration number for 1888,0601.460.c, while 1888,0601.443, which is an Attic black figure band cup, will be an error for 1924,1201.443, which is decorated in similar fashion to the sherds from the dinos and has a similar slip, fabric and thickness.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 74, p. 249, no. 343)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0021) (phase 2)
